builder

Class BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder<S>

  • java.lang.Object
    • base.NeighborGraphBase<S,java.util.List<S>>
      • base.IndexedNeighborGraphBase<S>
        • base.IndexedNavigableRootedNeighborGraphBase<S>
          • builder.BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder<S>
  • Type Parameters:
    S - The vertex type on which the graph structure is defined.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    IndexedNavigableRootedNeighborGraph<S>, IndexedNeighborGraph<S>, ModifiableNeighborGraph<S>, NavigableRootedNeighborGraph<S>, NeighborGraph<S>

    public class BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder<S>
extends IndexedNavigableRootedNeighborGraphBase<S>
implements ModifiableNeighborGraph<S>
    An extension of IndexedNavigableRootedNeighborGraphBase that implements the ModifiableNeighborGraph interface, designed for building graphs in a breadth-first fashion.

    The addVertex method in this implementation is unsupported. Instead, vertices are added to the graph via the join method (with the exception of the root vertex, which is specified in the constructor). The join method is implemented so as to enforce breadth-first construction (see the description).

    The indexing of the vertex set is defined by the insertion order under the graph construction.

    Author:
    pdokos

      • BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder

        public BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder(S root,
                                int numVerts,
                                int degree)
        Constructor for a BreadthFirstNeighborGraphBuilder with specified root vertex, which has a known number of vertices, and is of uniform vertex degree (i.e. a regular graph). By specifying numVerts and degree, this constructor preallocates the requisite memory for holding the graph. The index of the root vertex is set to 1.
        Parameters:
        numVerts - the designated number of vertices of the graph.
        degree - the designated valency of each vertex.

      • join

        public boolean join(S src,
           S tgt)
        This method provides restricted graph building capabilities in such a way as to enforce breadth-first construction. This is accomplished by imposing the requirement that either:
            (i) src and tgt are vertices of the graph whose distances from the root are within one of each other,
        -or-
           (ii) tgt is not currently a vertex of the graph, and src is either of maximal distance from the root or one unit less than the current maximal distance. In this case tgt is added as a new vertex of the graph, and has distance from the root one unit greater than that of the source. The index of the new vertex is set to one more than the index of the most recently added vertex

        Note that in the second case above, the src vertex is typically of distance from the root one unit less than the current maximal distance. A call to the join method with src being of maximal distance and tgt being a new vertex increases the maximal distance by one; this is done when initiating the addition of vertices in the next layer of the graph.

        With these restrictions, the vertices of the graph are added in a breadth-first fashion, and the distance from the root of any vertex never changes from its initial distance. Furthermore, under the indexing of the vertex set, the sets of vertices of any given distance from the root consist of intervals.

        Specified by:
        join in interface ModifiableNeighborGraph<S>
        Parameters:
        src - any object of type S which is equal to a vertex in the graph.
        tgt - any object of type S.
        Returns:
        true if src and tgt were successfully joined.

      • finish

        public void finish()
        Sets the state of building to finished, and sorts the neighbor lists according to the indexing on the vertices. This cannot be undone, subsequent calls to addVertex and join return false and do not modify the graph. If the graph was specified as regular, or as having a certain number of vertices upon construction, then this method should only be called when these conditions are true.
        Specified by:
        finish in interface ModifiableNeighborGraph<S>
